awd_titl_txt: Science Policy Research Report:  On the Relationships between Manufacturing, Innovation, National Competitiveness, and the Magnitude and Nature of Work
awd_abstract_narration:
Shifts in the global locus of manufacturing may affect not just production costs, but alter the nature and pace of innovation, as well as the amount and type of jobs. Despite growth in U.S. manufacturing value added, the number of U.S. manufacturing workers has declined with fewer middle income jobs and displaced workers experiencing persistent, large earnings losses. Increasing productivity and manufactured products that are demanded worldwide and require specialized knowledge and capabilities specific to the United States are important factors for the U.S. to increase its global share of manufacturing value added. Further, for the U.S. to maintain national security and capability to innovate in certain sectors, it likely must manufacture certain advanced products locally.

The report summarizes the existing literature on the global redistribution of manufacturing activity from developed to industrializing nations and the implications of those shifts for innovation, national security, and the magnitude and nature of work. The report provides recommendations for policy based on this scientific evidence and notes important areas for additional research. The report reviews publicly available data on longitudinal trends of the global distribution of manufacturing and employment in manufacturing and reviews scientific evidence on the relationship between manufacturing, innovation, national security, and economic and nature of employment.  A taxonomy for different categories of technology change in manufacturing, and a preliminary assessment of how each category of technology change may influence the magnitude and nature of employment differently is provided along with a discussion of possibilities for national action, critical areas for improved data collection, and scholarly study.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The global locus of manufacturing in terms of value added has been shifting dramatically over the last three decades from developed to developing nations. Classical economics suggests that global productivity gains achieved by shifting the location of manufacturing will outweigh the losses, although individual people, regions, or nations may experience losses. Under these assumptions, the primary challenge facing a national government seeking to reduce inequity is the redistribution of the global productivity gains.  However, more recent research shows that shifts in the global locus of manufacturing may affect not just production costs, but the nature and pace of innovation. Where moving manufacturing overseas reduces incentives for new technology development, gains from trade may be overstated.

In terms of jobs,both globalization and innovation have been associated with the polarization of wages and employment in the economy (e.g. more jobs with high wages or high skills and more jobs with low wages or low skills). This literature faces the limitations of coarse and aggregate data such as having to use education or wage percentile as a measure of skill, and having to use aggregate capital spending as a measure of technology adoption. To date, these measures have focused on IT and automation, and direct measurement of innovation on skill requirements has been lacking. Using data collected on the manufacturing shop floor, we directly measure the labor-demand effects of two forms of technological change—automation and parts consolidation. We show that aggregate measures of technological change can mask how different emerging technologies affect skills requirements in different ways. In our empirical context, automation polarizes the skills demanded of manufacturing shop floor operators as routine, codifiable tasks executed by machines instead of humans, while the remaining and newly created human tasks tend to require low and high skills. In constrast, parts consolidation converges skill demand as formerly divisible low and high skill tasks are transformed into a single indivisible task with medium skill requirements and higher cost of failure.

Our policy report provides recommendations for U.S. manufacturing policy and practice based on the scientific evidence, and notes important unanswered questions: For the U.S. to maintain and enhance its national comparative advantage – including economic growth, social welfare, and national security, it will likely have to manufacture certain advanced products locally.  Local manufacturing can have benefits for the capability to innovate, national security, and jobs. Products at the technical frontier with tacit knowledge, instable processes, and a lack of an understanding of the underlying science, it can be difficult to innovate without a local manufacturing facility. Advanced materials and processes at the technical frontier commonly have such traits. For national security, in certain security-critical areas, ensured access to and control over products can be critical.  Here, local manufacturing is part of a suite of imperfect tools, each with different advantages: Critical access and control can be managed through a combination of local and ally production, supply chain resiliency, technical redundancy, and a variety of technical innovations focused on assessing the trustworthiness of a device. Finally, manufacturing of products at the technical frontier can be associated with better-wage and better-skill jobs, including for people with only high-school or less levels of education. Notably, not all manufacturing subsectors have equal opportunities across the workforce, nor do all emerging technologies present equal opportunities.  Understanding these difference on a subsector and technology level will be critical to making informed policy.

In the end, the key to achieving this local manufacturing and growing our share of the global pie in terms of manufacturing value added, will not just be productivity, but to make products demanded world-wide and that due to our specialized scientific and worker knowledge and capabilities can’t be made anywhere else.
